posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
We are having some trouble using LEDs on our robot when the robot is disabled, we can run the command from the LED subsystem in disabledInit in robot.java, but we can only add the runsWhenDisabled boolean to a command file, not a subsystem…

How should we go about running the commands from the subsystem in robot.java when disabled, or can we run a command file in robot.java?

code

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked:
I create a trigger event for disable…

Then, in my bindings, I bind stuff to the event…

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Subsystems themselves don’t change behavior when the robot is disabled – only Commands (via the behavior of the CommandScheduler).  If you call methods of a Subsystem from disabledInit(), they should run.  That said…

You have at least two instances of LEDs, both of which try to initialize underlying hardware (e.g., the CANdle).  This typically causes a crash on FRC robots, or at least incorrect behavior.

One instance is created in RobotContainer:130

public final LEDs m_leds = new LEDs();

The other via getInstance() in LEDs.java:34

(and then called from Robot.java, line 22)

My guess is that this was done to get access to the LEDs subsystem in Robot.java.  The way you avoid doing this is answered by the post above – pay particular attention to the .ignoringDisable(true) decorator; that’s how you make a Command that can run while disabled.

Once you do this, you’ll no longer need the getInstance() method or the other singleton stuff – and I recommend you delete it.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: Still a little confused on where this code goes?

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
I recommend removing the singleton stuff because none of the other Subsystems in this codebase use it (they’re all constructed conventionally in RobotContainer), and because it’s not actually guarding anything (the constructor in LEDs is public).

It could be made to work, but if its functionality isn’t going to be used anyway, it’s better to remove it.

Xactlysharp:

Still a little confused on where this code goes?

RobotContainer for both code blocks.

The private static Trigger disabled() method can go anywhere outside of a method within the class.

The bindings should go in the configureButtonBindings() method or even just in the constructor, right above the call to configureButtonBindings() .

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: It seems that enabledAlert cannot be resolved, do I need to import something?

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: You should be able to remove that entire line of code.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: My apologies… That “enabledAlert” is from a totally different system and unrelated to what you need. Just delete that.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: No worries. I’ll test this when I get a chance
